title.justification: The title succinctly captures the central theme of the research, which is to revisit and analyze the role of populations in multi-agent communication protocols.

extractions.description: The paper reevaluates the conventional training protocols used for multi-agent communication, specifically focusing on the limitations of current population-level communication strategies in sender-receiver Lewis games. The authors propose an alternative training protocol called 'partitioning', which aims to limit co-adaptation among agents, thereby improving communicative success and language development within larger populations. Experimental results show that this new approach enhances communication with new agents and promotes the development of more compositional languages.

type.justification: The paper conducts several experimental analyses to test the proposed partitioning protocol and compare it with the standard training protocol. The focus is on empirical results and observations derived from these experiments.
type.quote: In experiments, we find that agents trained in partitioned populations are able to communicate successfully with new communication partners with which they have never interacted during training, and that languages spoken by various agents tend to be similar to one another.

name.justification: The study focuses on the emergence and development of structured languages among artificial agents, which falls under the broader domain of Natural Language Processing.
name.quote: Uncovering the mechanisms that underlie our ability to communicate using language is an important stepping stone towards developing machine learning models that are capable of coordinating and interacting via natural language.

name.justification: The research specifically targets the communication protocols and training paradigms in multi-agent systems.
name.quote: Over the last few years, there has been increasing interest in simulating the emergence of language using artificial agents trained with reinforcement learning to communicate to achieve a cooperative task.

name.justification: The study investigates how structured languages emerge in populations of communicating agents, making Language Emergence a key sub-research field.
name.quote: Typically, agents are trained to perform a variant of the Lewis signaling game [37, 51] wherein a sender emits a message describing an object and a receiver attempts to reconstruct the object based on the description.

name.justification: The Sender-Receiver Lewis Game is the primary model used in various configurations to study the communication protocols and language emergence among agents.
name.quote: Typically, agents are trained to perform a variant of the Lewis signaling game [37, 51] wherein a sender emits a message describing an object and a receiver attempts to reconstruct the object based on the description.

is_contributed.justification: The Sender-Receiver Lewis Game is a well-established model and is not introduced by this paper.
is_contributed.quote: Typically, agents are trained to perform a variant of the Lewis signaling game [37, 51] wherein a sender emits a message describing an object and a receiver attempts to reconstruct the object based on the description.

is_executed.justification: The model is implemented using neural networks and trained through gradient descent, which typically involves GPU execution.
is_executed.quote: In practice, both senders and receivers are implemented as neural networks πθ and ρψ with parameters θ and ψ estimated by gradient descent.

is_compared.justification: The performance of the Sender-Receiver Lewis Game under different training protocols is compared in the paper.
is_compared.quote: To shed light on this phenomenon, we analyze the behaviour of agents in a population at the equilibrium.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the seminal work by David Lewis that introduced the concept of signaling games.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Typically, agents are trained to perform a variant of the Lewis signaling game [37, 51] wherein a sender emits a message describing an object and a receiver attempts to reconstruct the object based on the description.

name.justification: The ImageNet dataset is used for experiments involving natural images, serving as a more realistic and complex dataset for evaluating communication protocols.
name.quote: Following Chaabouni et al. [10], we use the ImageNet [17] dataset of natural images.

referenced_paper_title.value: ImageNet: A large-scale hierarchical image database
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the original paper that introduces the ImageNet dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Following Chaabouni et al. [10], we use the ImageNet [17] dataset of natural images.

name.justification: This synthetic dataset is specifically used for controlled experiments to evaluate the generalization of communication protocols to unseen combinations of attributes.
name.quote: We perform experiments on two datasets: a simple, synthetic 'attribute/values' dataset and a more realistic image dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Compositionality and generalization in emergent languages
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is one of the key references that have used similar synthetic datasets to study language emergence.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Specifically, each input x is a vector of 4 attributes, each of which can take 10 total values. This results in 10^4 total attribute/value combinations [32, 9].

name.justification: The EGG toolkit, which is based on PyTorch, is used for implementing and running the experiments in the study.
name.quote: Our implementation, based on the EGG toolkit [29], will be open-sourced upon de-anonymization.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the foundational paper introducing PyTorch, which EGG is built upon.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Our implementation, based on the EGG toolkit [29], will be open-sourced upon de-anonymization.
